Award.AwardTitle: Cyber-Enabled Predictive Models for Polymer Nanocomposites: Multiresolution Simulations and Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
CMMI 0826356

Cyber-enabled predictive models for polymer nanocomposites: multiresolution simulations and experiments
PI: Alejandro Strachan, School of Materials Engineering, Purdue University
This CMMI project will develop an experimentally-validated, predictive modeling framework to describe the mechanical response of polymer nanocomposites. While the framework will be applicable to a wide range of materials this effort will focus on polyimides reinforced with carbon nanotubes and graphene sheets and the fundamental phenomena that govern the mechanical properties of these materials, including: i) the role of particle functionalization on dispersion and interfacial strength; ii) changes in polymer structure and properties near the particles; and iii) nucleation and propagation of mechanisms of inelastic deformation and failure. To achieve these objectives this project will utilize multi-resolution theoretical and experimental techniques starting with electrons and atoms via ab initio and molecular dynamics simulations and atomic force microscopy and also capturing mesoscale and macroscopic phenomena via phase field micromechanical modeling and mechanical characterization experiments.
This project will seek to maximize its impact and outreach to the research and educational communities by cyber-enabling the simulation tools and deploying educational content online via nanoHUB.org (developed by NSF?s Network for Computational Nanotechnology). nanoHUB enables users to run live simulations using simply a web-browser. Such a cyber-enabled, predictive tool for the simulation of polymer nanocomposites has the potential to help design next-generation materials with improved strength that will impact established industries including aerospace and automobile as well as emerging applications like micro electro-mechanical systems (MEMS). It is expected that this resource will be used by a large number of scientists and engineers in industry and national labs thus facilitating the technology transfer from academia to the end users who can transform it into products that benefit society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved simulations, ranging in scale from atomic level to macroscopic ones, and experiments, including synthesis and characterization, designed to understand and improve the ultimate mechanical response of polymer nanocomposites. These materials consist of a polymer matrix reinforced by carbon nanotubes.

Intelectual merit. The atomistic simulations resulted in a better understanding of the molecular processes that govern polymer properties including the development of energy-based yield criterion that captures volumetric and deviatoric loads.  In addition the simulations provide key information regarding how the reinforcements interact with each other through the matrix. At mesoscales (intermediate between atoms and the macroscale) the team developed a micromechanical model  that takes the results from the atomistic simulations and describes crack propagation in complex composite microstructures. In addition, the investigators combined multiscale modeling with experiments to demonstrate the importance of microstructural variability in crack initiation.

Experimentally, the team demonstrated the importance of achieving good dispersion of the carbon nanotubes in the polymer matrix to improve the mechanical response of the composite. The team also investigated new modes of operation of an atomic force microscope that enables the visualization of reinforcements buried into the matrix.

In summary, this project advanced the state-of-art in the field of polymer nanocomposites in various fronts leading to a deeper understanding of these materials at various scales, avenues to improve their properties and new characterization techniques.

Broader Impact. The main outreach efforts in this effort included the undergraduate research and cyber-enabling simulation tools via nanoHUB.org. The effort supported a total of 13 undergraduate students.

The team developed and deployed the PolymerModeler (https://nanohub.org/resources/polymod) a one-of-a-kind tool to build atomistic structures of amorphous polymer and perform MD simulations. The tool is available free of charge for any user in nanoHUB.org. The PolymerModeler tool, see Fig. 1, is useful both in research and education and has already been used by 386 users so far who performed over 10,000 online simulations. The team also deployed the Nanoindentation close to an interface tool (https://nanohub.org/resources/nanoin), the Composite Laminate Analysis tool (https://nanohub.org/resources/complam ) and the Free Edge Approximation for the Angle-Ply Laminate: (https://nanohub.org/resources/freeedge). This shows the power of online simulation and the ability of nanoHUB.org to lower the barriers to high-performance computing.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2014
Modified by: Alejandro H Strachan
